24 Hour Events:
   - Patient was admitted, right central line was placed, arterial line
   was placed.
   - Patient was given 2 L NS (received 5 L at OSH), then 4 L of LR for
   CVP <14 and/or SBP <90.
   - Abdominal ultrasound completed, liver was without abnormalities. No
   intra or extra-hepatic duct dilatation, CBD 3 mm, gall bladder
   [** 420**] so could not be assessed for stones. Patent portal flow
   without occlusion.
   - Surgery [**Name (NI) 420**] given abdominal distension and bladder pressure of
   38, worsening respiratory status. Surgery following closely for
   possible laparotomy if needed to relieve abdominal compartment
   syndrome.
   - ERCP team [**Name (NI) 420**], case discussed, given improving amylase, lipase,
   and LFTs, and lack of stone in CBD, appears he passed stone so no ERCP
   at this time.
   - Trials of changing over to AC to increase rate unsuccessful overnight

s PIP very high (50
s) and patient fighting ventilator.

s to 80

s. Cardiology felt

s. Decision not to

   - Patient
s family called and updated this AM, will be in to visit.
   - Temperature to 100, cultures drawn.

   Troponin-T:391/11/0.14, ALT / AST:74/81, Alk Phos / T Bili:98/0.7,
   Amylase / Lipase:1678/2450, Differential-Neuts:79.0 %, Band:7.0 %,
   Lymph:9.0 %, Mono:5.0 %, Eos:0.0 %, Lactic Acid:1.7 mmol/L, Albumin:2.6
   g/dL, LDH:299 IU/L, Ca++:6.9 mg/dL, Mg++:1.9 mg/dL, PO4:3.6 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 68 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found to have elevated pancreatic enzymes and LFTs,
   intubated for increased work of breathing, with hypotension, worsening
   renal function, and elevated cardiac enzymes overnight.
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated in setting of respiratory distress,
   also given need for aggressive IVF resuscitation. Did not tolerated
   several attempts at trials of AC, with PIP that were very high (>50),
   however this morning respiratory team was able to switch him over to
   AC. In setting of IVFs, needed to increase oxygen to 100% FiO2 from 70%
   to maintain oxygenation. Given that his acidosis is worsening
   (metabolic), would ideally like to go up on rate to help compensate
   further; this may require additional sedation and possibly a trial of
   paralytics. Increased abdominal pressure also is likely leading to
   higher pleural pressures, so additional data would be helpful.
   - Will place esophageal balloon to obtain data on pleural pressures,
   plateau pressures
   - Trending ABGs, CXR w/volume overload but no ARDS (will be mindful of
   potential of developing ARDS given severe pancreatitis)
   - Patient received levofloxacin for question of consolidation (versus
   atelectasis versus asp PNA) on CXR at OSH, also may have had
   aspiration, so will follow daily CXR
   - Will paralyze patient and see if able to better ventilate to improve
   oxygenation, BP, and pH
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFTs and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance.
   - Patient is status-post over 11 liters of IVF
based on discussion with
   ICU and surgical team, will hold on further IVF resuscitation as
   additional IVFs will further compromise respiratory status and have
   potential of significantly worsening abdominal compartment syndrome and
   necessitating laparotomy.
   - F/u final RUQ u/s
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time
   - Hold off on ERCP consulted, given it appears stone has passed
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given
   acuity of patient
s illness, however no evidence of infection at
   present.
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, lactate (lactate
   currently coming down, calcium stabilized after repleted)
   - CRP pending
   - Triglycerides pending
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance following abdominal for compartment
   syndrome
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Metabolic acidosis: In setting of ARF, lactate has been stable, was
   slightly rising (2.6) but then trending downward. Also hyperglycemia,
   and was initially resuscitated with normal saline.
   - As noted above, attempting to change to AC and increase rate to help
   optimize pH by blowing off Co2
   - Trend ABGs, lactate, treat hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Most likely secondary to significant third spacing of
   fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as
   SIRS from his pancreatitis. Do not suspect infection or sepsis, however
   cultures are pending. Also have to consider MI as possibility given EKG
   changes and elevated CK/Troponin. No recent steroid use to suspect
   adrenal insufficiency.
   - Cont neo, holding on further IVFs as noted above given concerns of
   worsening abd compartment syn and pulmonary edema. (CVP had been >14).
   Will likely add levophed if second pressor is needed.
   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above, cardiac echo cardiogram
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending.
   # EKG changes: Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2, with <1 mm of
   STE in inferior leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**]. However, TWI
   are new. Initial CK at OSH was elevated, with flat troponin and MB
   fraction negative. Patient does have h/o recent 4vCABG and new TWI are
   in the setting of intravascular hypovolemia, HCT drop. At this time,
   risks outweigh benefits for anticoagulation given concern of
   hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis. Given rising (but not very high)
   troponin levels, and appearance of EKG (although not markedly different
   from [**4-21**]), cardiology was [**Month/Year (2) 420**] and reviewed EKG and case, felt
   current EKG was not significantly different from old, STE could be
   ventricular aneurismal in nature. No other recommendations for change
   in management, as management of his pancreatitis was felt to be larger
   priority.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes
   - Serial EKGs
   - Will consider formal cardiology consult after echocardiogram is
   abnormal or should troponin markedly elevated.
   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue baby ASA
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated, start esmolol
   gtt
   - Transthoracic echo today.
   # Hyperkalemia: Improved,  in the setting of ARF, responded to IVFs and
   bicarbonate. No EKG changes c/w hyperkalemia.
   - Consider insulin/glucose, kayexalate
   - Follow trend, monitoring on telemetry.
   # ARF: Patient
s creatinine at presentation to OSH was 2.1, has been
   1.7-1.9 here. FENa 0.21% suggestive of pre-renal etiology, likely
   secondary to severe third spacing and relative hypovolemia, as well as
   abdominal compartment syndrome. Patient also received dye with CT at
   OSH. Anticipate given low urine output, borderline hypotension, that
   patient also will have component of ATN.
   - aggressive IVF hydration
   - urine lytes
   - renally dose meds
   - consider renal consult
   - Mucomist
   # Abdominal distension: Concern is for compartment syndrome in setting
   of elevated bladder pressure, distended abdomen, third spacing of
   fluids. Appreciate surgical assistance.
   - Continuing to monitor pressure, will see if paralytics improve
   bladder pressure. Should pressure rise >40, will need laparotory, which
   will be last resort.
   - Following trend of lactate, no evidence to suggest ischemic bowel or
   obstruction on imaging, no free air on CXR. SMA and aorta were free of
   significant atherosclerosis on CT.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now, nutrition consult for TPN
   Glycemic Control: Insulin drip
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2182-11-9**] 09:30 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2182-11-9**] 10:18 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2182-11-9**] 10:22 PM
   22 Gauge - [**2182-11-9**] 10:26 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication: Patient discussed on interdisciplinary rounds , ICU
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU
   Contact:
   Wife [**Name (NI) 1288**] (updated this morning)
   ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 7203**] (cell)
   ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 7204**] (home)

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, status-post CABG, who presents with hypotension, bradycardia, epigastric pain, and elevated pancreatic enzymes and LFTs. He is intubated for increased work of breathing and has worsening renal function and elevated cardiac enzymes. The patient has severe acute pancreatitis, likely secondary to gallstone pancreatitis, and is at risk for abdominal compartment syndrome.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is worsening, and he requires aggressive IVF resuscitation. He may require additional sedation and possibly a trial of paralytics to improve oxygenation.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is severe and may lead to further complications, such as abdominal compartment syndrome, sepsis, and multi-organ failure.
3. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's elevated bladder pressure and distended abdomen put him at risk for compartment syndrome, which may require laparotomy.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's acidosis is worsening, and he may require additional interventions to optimize his pH.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be secondary to third spacing of fluids in the abdomen, leading to hypovolemia, and may require further management with vasopressors.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's EKG changes and elevated cardiac enzymes may indicate cardiac damage, and he may require further evaluation with a cardiac echo cardiogram.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia has improved, but he may require further management with insulin and glucose.
8. Acute tubular necrosis: The patient's ARF may be secondary to pre-renal etiology, and he may require further management with aggressive IVF hydration and renally dosed medications.
9. Sepsis: The patient's SIRS and elevated cardiac enzymes may indicate sepsis, and he may require further evaluation and management.
10. Organ failure: The patient's pancreatitis and ARF may lead to multi-organ failure, and he may require further management with organ support.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and ventilated, and there is a risk of respiratory failure due to the severity of pancreatitis, hypovolemia, and metabolic acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient has severe pancreatitis, which increases the risk of developing sepsis. The presence of new TWI in V1, V2, STE in inferior leads on the EKG suggests possible cardiac involvement, which can also increase the risk of sepsis.
3. ARF (Acute Renal Failure): The patient has ARF in the setting of pancreatitis and hypovolemia, which can lead to further complications such as electrolyte imbalance, acidosis, and hyperkalemia.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a significant metabolic acidosis, which can lead to further complications such as respiratory failure, cardiac arrhythmias, and decreased tissue perfusion.
5. Hypotension: The patient has hypotension, which can be due to third spacing of fluids, pancreatitis, or cardiac involvement. This can lead to decreased tissue perfusion, organ dysfunction, and increased risk of sepsis.
6. Pancreatitis: The patient has severe pancreatitis, which can lead to further complications such as abscess formation, fistula, and multi-organ failure.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient has new TWI in V1, V2, STE in inferior leads on the EKG, which can indicate cardiac involvement. This can lead to further complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure, and increased risk of mortality.
8. Hyperkalemia: The patient has hyperkalemia, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure, and decreased cardiac output.
9. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing infections, particularly in the setting of pancreatitis and ARF.
10. Compartment syndrome: The patient has a high risk of developing compartment syndrome in the abdominal region, which can lead to further complications such as necrosis, organ dysfunction, and increased risk of mortality.

Based on the patient's condition, the following assessments and plans are recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's pancreatitis with aggressive IVF resuscitation, CVL, and A-line placement.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust treatment accordingly.
4. Continue to manage the patient's ARF with aggressive IVF hydration and renally dosed medications.
5. Monitor the patient's metabolic acidosis and adjust treatment accordingly.
6. Continue to manage the patient's hypotension with IVF resuscitation and vasopressors as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's pancreatic enzymes and adjust treatment accordingly.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust treatment accordingly.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac enzymes and adjust treatment accordingly.
10. Consider consulting a nephrologist for further management of the patient's ARF.

The patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and improve outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities, including acute pancreatitis, acute myocardial infarction (AMI), and hyperglycemia. The patient is sedated and unable to provide a history. The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, analgesics, and vasopressors. The patient's vital signs are stable, but they require ongoing hemodynamic monitoring and respiratory support.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's acute pancreatitis, acute myocardial infarction, and hyperglycemia, there is a high risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and they require ongoing mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of developing respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia and death.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's acute myocardial infarction increases the risk of cardiac complications, including cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac arrest.
4. Pancreatitis complications: The patient's acute pancreatitis can lead to complications such as pancreatic necrosis, abscess formation, and sepsis.
5. Hyperglycemia complications: The patient's hyperglycemia can lead to complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar nonketotic coma, and increased risk of infection.
6. Bloodstream infections: The patient's presence of central lines and arterial lines increases the risk of developing bloodstream infections, which can be life-threatening.
7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobility and presence of central lines increase the risk of developing DVT, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and death.
8. Stress ulcer: The patient's critical illness and presence of central lines increase the risk of developing stress ulcer, which can lead to bleeding and death.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and high-risk status, it is essential to closely monitor their condition and manage their care accordingly to prevent and manage potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 68 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found to have elevated pancreatic enzymes and LFTs,
   with ARDS and persistent pressor requirement, but improved abdominal
   pressures after paralyzed.
   # Respiratory failure: Hypoxemic respiratory failure and now ARDS.
   Intubated in setting of respiratory distress, also given need for
   aggressive IVF resuscitation. Initially did not tolerated AC, but
   necessary to switch over to AC given metabolic acidosis. Yesterday
   paralytics were initiated to attempt to lessen work of breathing and
   allow for synchrony on ventilator so patient could tolerate AC mode.
   This was successful, and esophageal balloon helped further titrate
   PEEP. Currently he now meets ARDS criteria in setting of pancreatitis
   and possible aspiration.
   - Will aim to stop paralytics today to lessen risk of myopathy and
   follow ABG
s to see if this is tolerated
   - Will aim to lower tidal volumes to reach lower volumes closer to ARDS
   net protocol (rate and tidal volumes were increased to rise minute
   ventilation to help with metabolic acidosis)
   - Continue antibiotics as noted below.
   - Continue sedation with fentanyl and versed.
   .
   #  Metabolic acidosis: In setting of ARF, lactate has been stable, and
   now trending downward. Working on treating hyperglycemia as well.
   - Will consult renal for further assistance managing acid base status,
   as appears patient likely will not need CVVH, but wish to have them
   aware and following in event this acidosis worsens or cannot improve
   with changing ventilator settings. Appreciate assistance
   - Will follow ABGs, weigh benefits lowering tidal volumes (and going up
   on rate) to help ARDS versus improving acidosis, consider bicarbonate
   supplementation
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFTs and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance.
   - Patient is status-post > 11 liters of IVF
based on discussion with
   ICU and surgical team, will hold on further IVF resuscitation as
   additional IVFs will further compromise respiratory status and have
   potential of significantly worsening abdominal compartment syndrome and
   necessitating laparotomy.
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time
   - Hold off on ERCP consulted, given it appears stone has passed, given
   LFTs and pancreatitic enzymes improving, no role at present, but will
   have low threshold to consider should status worsen
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given
   acuity of patient
s illness, however no evidence of infection at
   present (no necrosis seen on CT)
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, lactate (lactate
   currently coming down, calcium stabilized after repleted)
   - Triglycerides pending
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance following abdominal for compartment
   syndrome
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Most likely secondary to significant third spacing of
   fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as
   SIRS from his pancreatitis. Do not suspect infection or sepsis, however
   cultures are pending. Also have to consider MI as possibility given EKG
   changes and elevated CK/Troponin (but more likely cardiac enzyme leak
   from stress in setting of SIRS and hypotension, no EKG changes). No
   recent steroid use to suspect adrenal insufficiency.
   - Cont neo, holding on further IVFs as noted above given concerns of
   worsening abd compartment syn and pulmonary edema. (CVP had been >14).
   Vasopressin added yesterday given low SBP.
   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above, cardiac echocardiogram
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending.
   - Weaning pressors as tolerated (does of neo has lessened)
   # EKG changes: Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2, with <1 mm of
   STE in inferior leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**]. However, TWI
   are new. Initial CK at OSH was elevated, with flat troponin and MB
   fraction negative. Patient does have h/o recent 4vCABG and new TWI are
   in the setting of intravascular hypovolemia, blood pressure drop. At
   this time, risks continue to outweigh benefits for anticoagulation
   given concern of hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis. Given rising (but
   not very high) troponin levels, and appearance of EKG (although not
   markedly different from [**4-21**]), cardiology was contact[**Name (NI) **] and reviewed
   EKG and case, felt current EKG was not significantly different from
   old, STE could be ventricular aneurismal in nature. No other
   recommendations for change in management, as management of his
   pancreatitis was felt to be larger priority.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes

   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue ASA
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated, start esmolol

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, status-post CABG, who presents with hypotension, bradycardia, epigastric pain, and elevated pancreatic enzymes and liver function tests (LFTs). He is intubated due to respiratory distress and has been diagnosed with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and pancreatitis. He has been treated with antibiotics, vasopressors, and insulin for hyperglycemia. His laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.5, hemoglobin of 12.5, and platelet count of 194. His arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.28, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) of 39, and partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) of 116.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may lead to further respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and potentially necessitating extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) or other advanced respiratory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient's pancreatitis and potential infection may lead to sepsis, which can cause multi-organ dysfunction and increase the risk of mortality.
3. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal distension and elevated bladder pressure may lead to abdominal compartment syndrome, which can cause organ dysfunction and failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury (AKI) may progress to chronic kidney disease (CKD) or end-stage renal disease (ESRD), requiring dialysis.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponin levels and new T-wave inversions on his electrocardiogram (EKG) may indicate cardiac injury or infarction, which can increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
6. Infection: The patient's pancreatitis and potential infection may lead to sepsis, which can cause multi-organ dysfunction and increase the risk of mortality.
7. Hypovolemia: The patient's third spacing of fluids in his abdomen may lead to hypovolemia, which can cause decreased blood pressure, decreased cardiac output, and decreased organ perfusion.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may lead to further complications, such as ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar non-ketotic hyperglycemia, or even death.
9. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's pancreatitis and potential electrolyte imbalance may lead to electrolyte imbalances, such as hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, or hyperphosphatemia, which can cause cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or other complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary to prevent further respiratory failure.
2. Continue to treat the patient's pancreatitis with antibiotics and consider further imaging studies, such as a CT scan, to rule out necrotizing pancreatitis.
3. Monitor the patient's abdominal compartment syndrome and consider surgical intervention if necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management accordingly to prevent further AKI.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medication regimen as necessary to prevent cardiac complications.
6. Consider further imaging studies, such as a CT scan or MRI, to rule out other potential causes of the patient's symptoms.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his medication regimen as necessary to prevent electrolyte imbalances.
8. Consider further treatment options, such as surgery or interventional radiology, to address the patient's pancreatitis and potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 68 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found to have elevated pancreatic enzymes and LFTs,
   intubated for increased work of breathing, with hypotension, worsening
   renal function, and elevated cardiac enzymes overnight.
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated in setting of respiratory distress,
   also given need for aggressive IVF resuscitation. Did not tolerated
   several attempts at trials of AC, with PIP that were very high (>50),
   however this morning respiratory team was able to switch him over to
   AC. In setting of IVFs, needed to increase oxygen to 100% FiO2 from 70%
   to maintain oxygenation. Given that his acidosis is worsening
   (metabolic), would ideally like to go up on rate to help compensate
   further; this may require additional sedation and possibly a trial of
   paralytics. Increased abdominal pressure also is likely leading to
   higher pleural pressures, so additional data would be helpful.
   ARDS net protocol for ARDS
   - Will place esophageal balloon to obtain data on pleural pressures,
   plateau pressures
   - Trending ABGs, CXR w/volume overload but no ARDS (will be mindful of
   potential of developing ARDS given severe pancreatitis)
   - Patient received levofloxacin for question of consolidation (versus
   atelectasis versus asp PNA) on CXR at OSH, also may have had
   aspiration, so will follow daily CXR
   - Will paralyze patient and see if able to better ventilate to improve
   oxygenation, BP, and pH
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFTs and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance.
   - Patient is status-post over 11 liters of IVF
based on discussion with
   ICU and surgical team, will hold on further IVF resuscitation as
   additional IVFs will further compromise respiratory status and have
   potential of significantly worsening abdominal compartment syndrome and
   necessitating laparotomy.
   - F/u final RUQ u/s
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time
   - Hold off on ERCP consulted, given it appears stone has passed
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given
   acuity of patient
s illness, however no evidence of infection at
   present.
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, lactate (lactate
   currently coming down, calcium stabilized after repleted)
   - CRP pending
   - Triglycerides pending
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance following abdominal for compartment
   syndrome
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   ? d/c abx
   # Metabolic acidosis: In setting of ARF, lactate has been stable, was
   slightly rising (2.6) but then trending downward. Also hyperglycemia,
   and was initially resuscitated with normal saline.
   - As noted above, attempting to change to AC and increase rate to help
   optimize pH by blowing off Co2
   - Trend ABGs, lactate, treat hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Most likely secondary to significant third spacing of
   fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as
   SIRS from his pancreatitis. Do not suspect infection or sepsis, however
   cultures are pending. Also have to consider MI as possibility given EKG
   changes and elevated CK/Troponin. No recent steroid use to suspect
   adrenal insufficiency.
   - Cont neo, holding on further IVFs as noted above given concerns of
   worsening abd compartment syn and pulmonary edema. (CVP had been >14).
   Vasopressin added yesterday given low SBP.
   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above, cardiac echo cardiogram
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending.
   # EKG changes: Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2, with <1 mm of
   STE in inferior leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**]. However, TWI
   are new. Initial CK at OSH was elevated, with flat troponin and MB
   fraction negative. Patient does have h/o recent 4vCABG and new TWI are
   in the setting of intravascular hypovolemia, HCT drop. At this time,
   risks outweigh benefits for anticoagulation given concern of
   hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis. Given rising (but not very high)
   troponin levels, and appearance of EKG (although not markedly different
   from [**4-21**]), cardiology was contact[**Name (NI) **] and reviewed EKG and case, felt
   current EKG was not significantly different from old, STE could be
   ventricular aneurismal in nature. No other recommendations for change
   in management, as management of his pancreatitis was felt to be larger
   priority.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes
   - Serial EKGs
   - Will consider formal cardiology consult after echocardiogram is
   abnormal or should troponin markedly elevated.
   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue baby ASA
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated, start esmolol
   gtt
   - Transthoracic echo today.
   # Hyperkalemia: Improved,  in the setting of ARF, responded to IVFs and
   bicarbonate. No EKG changes c/w hyperkalemia.
   - Consider insulin/glucose, kayexalate
   - Follow trend, monitoring on telemetry.
   # ARF: Patient
s creatinine at presentation to OSH was 2.1, has been

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 68 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found to have elevated pancreatic enzymes and LFTs,
   intubated for increased work of breathing, with hypotension, worsening
   renal function, and elevated cardiac enzymes overnight.
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated in setting of respiratory distress,
   also given need for aggressive IVF resuscitation. Did not tolerated
   several attempts at trials of AC, with PIP that were very high (>50),
   however this morning respiratory team was able to switch him over to
   AC. In setting of IVFs, needed to increase oxygen to 100% FiO2 from 70%
   to maintain oxygenation. Given that his acidosis is worsening
   (metabolic), would ideally like to go up on rate to help compensate
   further; this may require additional sedation and possibly a trial of
   paralytics. Increased abdominal pressure also is likely leading to
   higher pleural pressures, so additional data would be helpful.
   ARDS net protocol for ARDS
   - Will place esophageal balloon to obtain data on pleural pressures,
   plateau pressures
   - Trending ABGs, CXR w/volume overload but no ARDS (will be mindful of
   potential of developing ARDS given severe pancreatitis)
   - Patient received levofloxacin for question of consolidation (versus
   atelectasis versus asp PNA) on CXR at OSH, also may have had
   aspiration, so will follow daily CXR
   - Will paralyze patient and see if able to better ventilate to improve
   oxygenation, BP, and pH
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFTs and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance.
   - Patient is status-post over 11 liters of IVF
based on discussion with
   ICU and surgical team, will hold on further IVF resuscitation as
   additional IVFs will further compromise respiratory status and have
   potential of significantly worsening abdominal compartment syndrome and
   necessitating laparotomy.
   - F/u final RUQ u/s
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time
   - Hold off on ERCP consulted, given it appears stone has passed
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given
   acuity of patient
s illness, however no evidence of infection at
   present.
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, lactate (lactate
   currently coming down, calcium stabilized after repleted)
   - CRP pending
   - Triglycerides pending
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance following abdominal for compartment
   syndrome
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   ? d/c abx
   # Metabolic acidosis: In setting of ARF, lactate has been stable, was
   slightly rising (2.6) but then trending downward. Also hyperglycemia,
   and was initially resuscitated with normal saline.
   - As noted above, attempting to change to AC and increase rate to help
   optimize pH by blowing off Co2
   - Trend ABGs, lactate, treat hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Most likely secondary to significant third spacing of
   fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as
   SIRS from his pancreatitis. Do not suspect infection or sepsis, however
   cultures are pending. Also have to consider MI as possibility given EKG
   changes and elevated CK/Troponin. No recent steroid use to suspect
   adrenal insufficiency.
   - Cont neo, holding on further IVFs as noted above given concerns of
   worsening abd compartment syn and pulmonary edema. (CVP had been >14).
   Vasopressin added yesterday given low SBP.
   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above, cardiac echo cardiogram
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending.
   # EKG changes: Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2, with <1 mm of
   STE in inferior leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**]. However, TWI
   are new. Initial CK at OSH was elevated, with flat troponin and MB
   fraction negative. Patient does have h/o recent 4vCABG and new TWI are
   in the setting of intravascular hypovolemia, HCT drop. At this time,
   risks outweigh benefits for anticoagulation given concern of
   hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis. Given rising (but not very high)
   troponin levels, and appearance of EKG (although not markedly different
   from [**4-21**]), cardiology was contact[**Name (NI) **] and reviewed EKG and case, felt
   current EKG was not significantly different from old, STE could be
   ventricular aneurismal in nature. No other recommendations for change
   in management, as management of his pancreatitis was felt to be larger
   priority.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes
   - Serial EKGs
   - Will consider formal cardiology consult after echocardiogram is
   abnormal or should troponin markedly elevated.
   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue baby ASA
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated, start esmolol
   gtt
   - Transthoracic echo today.
   # Hyperkalemia: Improved,  in the setting of ARF, responded to IVFs and
   bicarbonate. No EKG changes c/w hyperkalemia.
   - Consider insulin/glucose, kayexalate
   - Follow trend, monitoring on telemetry.
   # ARF: Patient
s creatinine at presentation to OSH was 2.1, has been
   1.7-1.9 here. FENa 0.21% suggestive of pre-renal etiology, likely
   secondary to severe third spacing and relative hypovolemia, as well as
   abdominal compartment syndrome. Patient also received dye with CT at
   OSH. Anticipate given low urine output, borderline hypotension, that
   patient also will have component of ATN.
   ? Renal c/s
   - aggressive IVF hydration
   - urine lytes
   - renally dose meds
   - consider renal consult
   - Mucomist
   # Abdominal distension: Concern is for compartment syndrome in setting
   of elevated bladder pressure, distended abdomen, third spacing of
   fluids. Appreciate surgical assistance.
   - Continuing to monitor pressure, will see if paralytics improve
   bladder pressure. Should pressure rise >40, will need laparotory, which
   will be last resort.
   - Following trend of lactate, no evidence to suggest ischemic bowel or
   obstruction on imaging, no free air on CXR. SMA and aorta were free of
   significant atherosclerosis on CT.
   # Leukocytosis: New WBC to 13.5, differential from [**11-9**] with 7 bands.
   No overwhelming evidence of infection, but has had low grade
   temperatures

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, status-post CABG, who presents with hypotension, bradycardia, epigastric pain, elevated pancreatic enzymes, and LFTs. He was intubated for increased work of breathing and has been receiving aggressive IVF resuscitation. The patient has severe pancreatitis, likely caused by gallstones, and is at risk for ARDS, abdominal compartment syndrome, and metabolic acidosis. He also has elevated cardiac enzymes, suggesting possible myocardial infarction or cardiac injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory failure and worsening acidosis increase the risk of ARDS.
2. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome (ACS): The patient's elevated bladder pressure and distended abdomen increase the risk of ACS, which can lead to organ failure and death.
3. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's acidosis is worsening, and further respiratory support and metabolic management are needed to optimize pH.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes and possible myocardial infarction or cardiac injury increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
5. Infection: The patient's pancreatitis and elevated white blood cell count increase the risk of infection, particularly in the respiratory and abdominal tracts.
6. Renal Failure: The patient's acute kidney injury (AKI) and possible ATN increase the risk of renal failure, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and death.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia can worsen cardiac function and increase the risk of arrhythmias.
8. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can worsen organ perfusion and increase the risk of organ failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue aggressive IVF resuscitation to optimize fluid status and prevent further organ dysfunction.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider further respiratory support, such as increasing the FiO2 or adjusting the ventilator settings.
3. Manage the patient's acidosis by adjusting the ventilator settings, administering bicarbonate, and optimizing glucose control.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac enzymes and consider further cardiac evaluation, such as an echocardiogram, to assess cardiac function and rule out cardiac complications.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's white blood cell count and consider further antibiotic therapy if infection is suspected.
6. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider further renal support, such as dialysis, if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's potassium levels closely and consider further management, such as insulin and glucose, if hyperkalemia persists.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and consider further management, such as vasopressors, if hypotension persists.

Based on the provided 24-hour progress note, the patient's condition remains critical. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a plateau pressure of 24 cmH2O, indicating a high risk of ventilator-associated lung injury. The increased minute ventilation and PEEP suggest ongoing respiratory distress.

The patient's blood pressure is being maintained above 90 mmHg with vasopressin and phenylephrine infusions. The patient's heart rate is elevated at 102 bpm, and their SpO2 is 93%. The patient's temperature is 38.2C (100.8F), which is slightly elevated.

The patient's fluid balance is being closely monitored, with a total input of 9,622 mL and a total output of 9,488 mL, resulting in a positive balance of 8,927 mL. The patient's urine output has been steady to improved, which is a positive sign.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating ongoing cardiac injury. The patient's lactate level is 2.2 mmol/L, which is slightly elevated, suggesting ongoing tissue hypoperfusion.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their intubation and sedation, but they are responding to stimuli.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Ventilator-associated lung injury (VALI) due to the high plateau pressure.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure due to the elevated troponin-T levels.
3. Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's ongoing respiratory and cardiac instability.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to the patient's fluid overload and potential renal hypoperfusion.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding or stress ulceration due to the patient's acid-base imbalance and ongoing respiratory distress.

Further monitoring and management of the patient's condition is necessary to prevent these potential complications and improve their outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old man with severe pancreatitis, hypoxemic respiratory failure, non-oliguric acute renal failure, and possible IMI. He has been in the ICU for several days and has undergone various interventions, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and paralytics. His current vital signs include a heart rate of 98 bpm, blood pressure of 100/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 93%. He has a history of abdominal compartment syndrome, which has responded to conservative management.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he requires mechanical ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation. Prolonged mechanical ventilation can lead to ventilator-associated pneumonia, lung injury, and respiratory muscle weakness.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and low-grade fever suggest the possibility of sepsis. Sepsis can lead to organ dysfunction, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's non-oliguric AKI may progress to oliguric AKI, which can increase the risk of mortality.
4. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's decreased ejection fraction (EF) and suspected sepsis-associated cardiomyopathy may lead to cardiac failure, arrhythmias, and decreased cardiac output.
5. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal compartment syndrome may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's reliance on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) may lead to nutritional deficiencies, including electrolyte imbalances and impaired wound healing.
8. Infection: The patient's broad empiric antibiotics may not cover the underlying infection, leading to treatment failure and increased risk of mortality.
9. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's vasopressor dependence and decreased cardiac output may lead to hemodynamic instability, including hypotension and tachycardia.
10. Neurological complications: The patient's prolonged sedation and paralysis may lead to neurological complications, including delirium, seizures, and weakness.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old man who presented with hypotension, pancreatitis, acute renal failure, and possible IMI. He has been in the ICU for several days and has been treated with various medications, including vasopressors, antibiotics, and sedatives. His vital signs are stable, but his respiratory status is concerning, with a low oxygen saturation and a high respiratory rate. He has a history of abdominal compartment syndrome, which is being managed conservatively. He is also at risk for cardiac complications, including acute kidney injury and cardiac arrest.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of NSTEMI and decreased left ventricular function increases his risk for cardiac arrest.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further complications such as fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's low oxygen saturation and high respiratory rate indicate a high risk for respiratory failure, which may lead to further complications such as pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
4. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome: The patient's abdominal compartment syndrome may worsen, leading to further complications such as organ dysfunction and death.
5. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and low-grade fever indicate a risk for sepsis, which may lead to further complications such as organ dysfunction and death.
6. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to further complications such as pancreatic necrosis and multiorgan dysfunction.
7. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's borderline potassium levels and metabolic acidosis indicate a risk for electrolyte imbalance, which may lead to further complications such as cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further deterioration.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 68 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found to have elevated pancreatic enzymes and LFTs,
   with ARDS and persistent pressor requirement, but improved abdominal
   pressures after paralyzed.
   # Respiratory failure: Hypoxemic respiratory failure and now ARDS.
   Intubated in setting of respiratory distress, also given need for
   aggressive IVF resuscitation. Patient was on paralytics for about 24
   hours to facilitate tolerance of AC mode and lessen resistance.
   Currently he now meets ARDS criteria in setting of pancreatitis and
   possible aspiration. Overnight with desaturation while bathing, but now
   Fi02 back down to 80%, have successfully weaned TV
s to 550 with
   improved pH.
   - Will continue current settings, weaning FiO2 if possible, using lower
   tidal volumes to reach lower volumes closer to ARDS net protocol (rate
   and tidal volumes were increased to rise minute ventilation to help
   with metabolic acidosis)
   - Continue antibiotics as noted below.
   - Continue sedation with fentanyl and versed.
   .
   #  Metabolic acidosis: Improving as renal function improves and
   ventilatory settings optimized. Suspect this was mainly secondary to
   acute renal failure.
   - Appreciate renal assistance, now appears that renal function
   improving and his acidosis will hopefully continue to improve as well.
   Bicarbonate drip will be consideration should acidosis worsen.
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFTs and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance.
   Abdominal exam overall unchanged today.
   - Patient is status-post > 11 liters of IVF
based on discussion with
   ICU and surgical team, will hold on further IVF resuscitation as
   additional IVFs will further compromise respiratory status and have
   potential of significantly worsening abdominal compartment syndrome and
   necessitating laparotomy.
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time
   - Hold off on ERCP consulted, given it appears stone has passed, given
   LFTs and pancreatitic enzymes improving, no role at present, but will
   have low threshold to consider should status worsen
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given
   acuity of patient
s illness, however no evidence of infection at
   present (no necrosis seen on CT)
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, lactate (lactate
   currently coming down, calcium stabilized after repleted)
   - Triglycerides pending
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance following abdominal for compartment
   syndrome, and now in setting of fevers.
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Most likely secondary to significant third spacing of
   fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as
   SIRS from his pancreatitis. Do not suspect infection or sepsis, however
   cultures are pending. Also have to consider MI as possibility given EKG
   changes and elevated CK/Troponin (but more likely cardiac enzyme leak
   from stress in setting of SIRS and hypotension, no EKG changes). No
   recent steroid use to suspect adrenal insufficiency.
   - Cont neo, holding on further IVFs as noted above given concerns of
   worsening abd compartment syn and pulmonary edema. (CVP had been >14).
   Vasopressin added yesterday given low SBP.
   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above, cardiac echocardiogram
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending.
   - Weaning pressors as tolerated (does of neo has lessened)
   # EKG changes, history of CAD: Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2,
   with <1 mm of STE in inferior leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**].
   Initial CK at OSH was elevated, with flat troponin and MB fraction
   negative. Patient does have h/o recent 4vCABG in 6/[**2181**]. At this time,
   risks continue to outweigh benefits for anticoagulation given concern
   of hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis. Given rising troponin levels,
   and appearance of EKG (although not markedly different from [**4-21**]),
   cardiology was contact[**Name (NI) **] and reviewed EKG and case, felt current EKG
   was not significantly different from old, STE could be ventricular
   aneurismal in nature. No other recommendations for change in
   management, as management of his pancreatitis was felt to be larger
   priority.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes (will likely remain elevated in setting of
   his renal failure as will be slow to clear)
   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue ASA (PR while NG tube is to suction)
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated once off
   pressors, start esmolol gtt
   - Transthoracic echo today as noted above, suspect depressed function
   noted could be in setting of SIRS
   # ARF: Marked improvement to 1.9 today. Suspected ATN secondary to
   severe third spacing and relative hypovolemia causing hypotension, also
   with possible component of abdominal compartment syndrome. Patient also
   received dye with CT at OSH so contrast nephropathy also a possibility.
   Urine output has picked up today with 100-150 today (as opposed to
   10-20 cc/hr initially)
   - Hopefull that he will be able to avoid dialysis given what appears to
   be post-ATN diuresis, but obtained renal consult to help manage him in
   event that his volume status, hyperkalemia, and/or acidosis become
   difficult to manage. Appreciate assistance.
   - Supportive care as noted above, continuing to treat hyperkalemia (on
   insulin gtt), acidosis, monitoring urine output (no phos in TPN)
   # Abdominal distension: Concern was for compartment syndrome in setting
   of elevated bladder pressure, distended abdomen, third spacing of
   fluids. Appreciate surgical assistance. Bladder pressures are currently
   in teens now.
   - Following trend of lactate, no evidence to suggest ischemic bowel or
   obstruction on imaging, no free air on CXR. SMA and aorta were free of
   significant atherosclerosis on CT.
   # Leukocytosis: New WBC to 13.5, differential from [**11-9**] with 7 bands.
   No overwhelming evidence of infection, but has had low grade
   temperatures. Must consider infection of necrotic pancreas, but no
   intervention at this time given he is already on appropriate antibiotic
   coverage and has only had low grade temperatures, and pressor
   requirement is lessening.
   -          F/u final CXR read
   -          F/u cx data
   -          Cont antibiotics as noted above.
   -          Hold on repeat imaging of abd (would need contrast to fully
   evaluate), but if status dramatically worsens, would consider CT guided
   biopsy of pancreatic

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, status-post CABG, who presents with hypotension, bradycardia, epigastric pain, and elevated pancreatic enzymes and liver function tests (LFTs). He has been intubated and is being treated for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and septic shock. The patient has been diagnosed with severe acute pancreatitis, likely due to gallstones, and has developed metabolic acidosis, which is improving with optimization of ventilatory settings and renal function.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Respiratory failure: Hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
2. Metabolic acidosis: Improving with optimization of ventilatory settings and renal function.
3. Pancreatitis: Severe acute pancreatitis with suspected gallstone etiology.
4. Hypotension: Secondary to third spacing of fluids in the abdomen from pancreatitis and SIRS.
5. Leukocytosis: New WBC count of 13.5 with a differential of 7 bands, suggesting possible infection.
6. Abdominal distension: Concern for compartment syndrome due to elevated bladder pressure, distended abdomen, and third spacing of fluids.
7. Hypernatremia: Currently being treated with D5W.

The patient's current management includes:

1. Intubation and mechanical ventilation for ARDS.
2. Vasopressors for hypotension.
3. Antibiotics for suspected infection.
4. Insulin drip for hyperglycemia.
5. TPN with lipids for nutrition.
6. Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: Prolonged mechanical ventilation, respiratory arrest, or ventilator-associated pneumonia.
2. Metabolic acidosis: Further deterioration of acidosis, leading to organ failure.
3. Pancreatitis: Worsening of pancreatitis, leading to necrosis, abscess, or sepsis.
4. Hypotension: Further deterioration of hypotension, leading to organ failure or death.
5. Leukocytosis: Development of sepsis or multi-organ dysfunction syndrome.
6. Abdominal distension: Complications such as abdominal compartment syndrome, bowel obstruction, or necrosis.
7. Hypernatremia: Further deterioration of hypernatremia, leading to seizures, brain damage, or death.

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management by the ICU team to prevent or minimize these potential complications.

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has hypoxemic respiratory failure and is intubated. The ventilator settings are being adjusted to optimize respiratory support.
2. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a pH of 7.28, and the acidosis is likely secondary to acute renal failure. Bicarbonate drip may be considered if the acidosis worsens.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient has severe acute pancreatitis, and the gallstones seen on CT imaging suggest gallstone pancreatitis. The patient is at risk for SIRS, and the abdominal exam is unchanged.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely secondary to third spacing of fluids in the abdomen, leading to hypovolemia, and SIRS from pancreatitis. The vasopressors are being weaned as tolerated.
5. ARF: The patient has marked improvement in renal function, but the cause is unclear. The patient may have ATN secondary to severe third spacing and relative hypovolemia, or contrast nephropathy from the CT scan.
6. Abdominal distension: The patient has concern for abdominal compartment syndrome, and the bladder pressures are currently in the teens.
7. Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count is elevated, but there is no overwhelming evidence of infection.
8. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, and D5W may be needed to correct this.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, status-post CABG, who presented with hypotension, bradycardia, and epigastric pain. He was found to have severe pancreatitis with ARDS and persistent pressor requirement. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His condition has improved overnight, with a decrease in pressor requirement and an increase in oxygenation. He continues to have metabolic acidosis, which is being managed with bicarbonate therapy. The patient has also developed diarrhea and has a NG tube with bilious drainage.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's ARDS is likely to continue, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
2. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's acidosis may worsen if his renal function does not improve, and he may require further bicarbonate therapy.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is likely to continue, and he may require continued antibiotics and supportive care.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen if his fluid status does not improve, and he may require further pressor therapy.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection, particularly in his pancreatitis and ARDS, and may require further antibiotics and supportive care.
6. Sepsis: The patient's SIRS and hypotension may worsen if he develops sepsis, and he may require further antibiotics and supportive care.
7. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome: The patient's abdominal distension may worsen if he develops abdominal compartment syndrome, and he may require further supportive care and possible surgical intervention.
8. Renal Failure: The patient's ARF may worsen if his renal function does not improve, and he may require further supportive care and possible dialysis.
9. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia may worsen if his potassium levels do not improve, and he may require further therapy.
10. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of CAD and recent CABG may increase his risk for cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or arrhythmias.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to manage the patient's ARDS.
2. Continue antibiotics and supportive care to manage the patient's pancreatitis and SIRS.
3. Monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust his fluid therapy as needed to manage his hypotension and acidosis.
4. Consider further imaging studies, such as CT scans, to evaluate the patient's pancreatitis and ARDS.
5. Consider further laboratory studies, such as blood cultures and urine cultures, to evaluate the patient's infection and SIRS.
6. Consider further therapy, such as vasopressors and inotropes, to manage the patient's hypotension and cardiac function.
7. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid therapy and medication as needed to manage his ARF and hyperkalemia.
8. Consider further therapy, such as insulin and bicarbonate, to manage the patient's hyperglycemia and metabolic acidosis.
9. Consider further therapy, such as heparin and aspirin, to manage the patient's DVT and stress ulcer prophylaxis.
10. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust his therapy as needed to manage his cardiac complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-inch tall male who has been in the ICU for an unknown duration. He has been on vasopressin, insulin, phenylephrine, midazolam, and fentanyl infusions. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 92 bpm, blood pressure of 108/69 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 92%. He is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 80%. His laboratory results show acute kidney injury, metabolic acidosis, and hyperglycemia. He has a history of acute pancreatitis, myocardial infarction, and respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is on mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of developing VAP.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating AKI. This may be due to sepsis, hypovolemia, or other factors.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's pH is 7.28, indicating metabolic acidosis. This may be due to kidney failure, sepsis, or other factors.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose levels are elevated, indicating hyperglycemia. This may be due to insulin resistance, sepsis, or other factors.
5. Pancreatitis: The patient has a history of acute pancreatitis, which may be exacerbating his metabolic acidosis and hyperglycemia.
6. Myocardial infarction: The patient has a history of myocardial infarction, which may be contributing to his metabolic acidosis and hyperglycemia.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation, which may indicate respiratory failure. This may be due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pneumonia, or other factors.
8. Sepsis: The patient has a fever and is on vasopressin, which may indicate sepsis. This may be due to a variety of factors, including pneumonia, pancreatitis, or other infections.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Adjust the patient's medication regimen as necessary to manage his acidosis, hyperglycemia, and other complications.
3. Consider initiating renal replacement therapy if the patient's AKI worsens.
4. Consider adjusting the patient's mechanical ventilation settings to improve his oxygenation and ventilation.
5. Consider initiating antibiotics if the patient develops signs of sepsis or infection.
6. Consider consulting with a cardiologist or intensivist to manage the patient's cardiac and respiratory complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress as follows:

The patient is a 63-year-old man with severe pancreatitis and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently receiving vasopressors and respiratory support. His vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 102.0F (38.9C)
* Heart rate: 93 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 89/63 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 28 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 91%
* Hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure (CVP) of 9 mmHg and a bladder pressure of 9 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 13.5-13.6 K/uL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 36.5-34.7%
* Platelet count (Plt): 150-153 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 3.1-2.4 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.94-1.41 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 2.2 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.8 g/dL
* LDH: 871 IU/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate (PO4): 2.9 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Transthoracic echo: dilated left atrium (LA) and right ventricle (RV) with depressed systolic function. No significant valvular abnormalities were noted.

The patient's assessment and plan are as follows:

* The patient is critically ill with severe pancreatitis and MODS.
* Renal function is improving.
* The patient is febrile, which may be due to progressive pancreatitis, necrosis, and infection.
* A computed tomography (CT) scan with contrast is not recommended due to the patient's creatinine level and the potential for the study to not alter management.
* The patient is receiving vancomycin, flagyl, and ciprofloxacin for now, pending the results of a c. difficile assay.
* The patient's troponin levels are elevated, but the primary cardiac event is uncertain.
* The plan is to continue to manage the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status, and to monitor for signs of sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Progressive pancreatitis and necrosis
* Infection, including sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction
* Cardiac complications, including heart failure and arrhythmias
* Respiratory failure, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Renal failure, including acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Neurological complications, including sepsis-related encephalopathy
* Coagulopathy, including disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Based on the patient's condition and the potential complications that may arise, it is essential to continue to monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies closely, and to adjust his management plan accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old man with severe pancreatitis and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). He is febrile with a temperature of 102.0F (38.9C), and his blood cultures are negative. His respiratory status is stable, but his cardiac function is compromised, with a decreased ejection fraction on echocardiogram. His renal function is improving, and his blood pressure is labile, requiring vasopressors.

Potential medical complications:

1. Progressive pancreatitis and necrosis: The patient's fever and GNR in sputum may indicate ongoing infection, which could lead to worsening pancreatitis and necrosis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but his oxygen saturation is 91%, and his PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 81, indicating some degree of hypoxia.
3. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's echocardiogram shows decreased ejection fraction, which could lead to cardiac failure and decreased cardiac output.
4. Renal failure: Although the patient's renal function is improving, he may still be at risk for acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Sepsis: The patient's febrile response and GNR in sputum may indicate sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
6. C. difficile infection: The patient is receiving metronidazole, which could lead to C. difficile infection if not properly monitored.
7. VAP: The patient is at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to his prolonged mechanical ventilation.
8. DVT: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to his immobility and underlying medical conditions.
9. Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk for stress ulcer due to his critical illness and prolonged mechanical ventilation.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve his clinical outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, status-post CABG, who presents with hypotension, bradycardia, epigastric pain, and severe pancreatitis with ARDS. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His respiratory status has improved, and he is now able to come off pressors. His renal function has also improved, and his acidosis is resolving.

The patient has been diagnosed with severe acute pancreatitis, likely secondary to gallstones, and is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics. He has been treated with IV fluids, insulin, and vasopressors, and has had a significant amount of fluid resuscitation.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.2, a hemoglobin level of 11.0 g/dL, and a platelet count of 131. His lactate level is normal, and his triglycerides are within normal limits.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function may deteriorate, leading to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
4. Sepsis: The patient's SIRS may progress to sepsis, leading to organ dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.
5. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal compartment syndrome may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac enzymes have peaked, and he has a history of CAD. He may be at risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or myocardial infarction.
7. Infection: The patient's wound infection may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.
8. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and increased risk of mortality.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as necessary.

5. Monitor the patient's abdominal compartment syndrome and adjust his fluid management and diuretic therapy as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medication therapy as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's wound infection and adjust his antibiotic therapy as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's fluid overload and adjust his fluid management and diuretic therapy as necessary.

   Fi02 back down to 80%, have successfully weaned TV
s to 550 with
   improved pH. Suspect that in setting of RV dysfunction noted on
   transthoracic echo (likely from ARDS and positive-pressure ventilation,

   pre-load/venous return leading to hypotension with preferential
   vasocontrction and resultant transient hypoxia.

   5
 per wife), around 450 cc, will increase respiratory rate as
   needed should pH worsen, goal pH >7.20
   - Wean FiO2 as tolerated for goal pO2 >60
   - Continue vancomycin and meropenem for empiric coverage, will consider
   additional of 2^nd [**Doctor Last Name **] to cover gram negative rods in sputum. If c.
   difficile negative, will stop flagyl as it provides redundant coverage
   (already on meropenem)
   - Continue sedation with fentanyl and versed.
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis: Much improved overnight as renal function
   improves and ventilatory settings optimized. Suspect this was mainly
   secondary to acute renal failure.
   - Appreciate renal assistance, now appears that renal function
   improving and his acidosis will hopefully continue to improve as well.
   Bicarbonate drip will be consideration should acidosis worsen.
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFT
s and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance. No
   change in abdominal examination.
   - Patient is status-post > 11 liters of IVF
had held off on further
   fluid resuscitation for hypotension given concerns about oxygenation
   and worsening of abdominal compartment syndrome in setting of poor
   urine output. Given that his bladder pressure is now 9 and he has
   significant (likely post-ATN) auto-diuresis, will aim to wean pressors
   and bolus with fluids as long as respiratory status is stable.
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time, as this would
   have risk of further dye exposure in setting of resolving ARF, and
   already on appropriate antibiotics (and HD stable, so surgical
   intervention not desired)
   - ERCP team aware of patients.
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given

   - Appreciate surgical assistance.
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Decreasing pressor requirement is encouraging.
   Hypotension with movement as noted above likely secondary to decreased
   venous return and forward flow with movement. Overall hypotension most
   likely secondary to significant third spacing of fluids in abdomen from
   pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as SIRS from his
   pancreatitis. No new clear wall motion abnormalities on transthoracic
   echocardiogram. Also in setting of post-ATN diuresis and new diarrhea
   and fevers with insensible losses. Do not suspect sepsis from infection
   as pressor need decreasing.
   - Cont neo (did not tolerate trial of levophed which caused
   tachycardia), wean as tolerated. If oxygenation is stable with new vent
   settings, will aim to further wean pressors and bolus instead given

   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above (just for purposes of noting
   peak)
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending, as noted above.
   # EKG changes, history of CAD: Do not suspect new ischemic event, but

   # ARF: Marked improvement to 1.9 today. Suspected ATN secondary to

   - Hopefull that he will be able to avoid dialysis given what appears to

   # Abdominal distension: Much improved, bladder pressure now 9.

   be post-ATN diuresis, but obtained renal consult to help manage him in
   event that his volume status, hyperkalemia, and/or acidosis become
   difficult to manage. Appreciate assistance.
   - Supportive care as noted above, continuing to treat hyperkalemia (on
   insulin gtt), acidosis, monitoring urine output (no phos in TPN)
   # Abdominal distension: Much improved, bladder pressure now 9.
   # Leukocytosis: Stable WBC to 13.5 today. Diarrhea overnight. Continues
   to have temperatures, overnight to 102. Must consider infection of
   necrotic pancreas, but no intervention at this time given he is already
   on appropriate antibiotic coverage and has only had low grade
   temperatures, and pressor requirement is lessening, and no necrosis
   seen on CT of abdomen.
   -          Follow up on culture data, added 2nd [**Doctor Last Name **] for gram
   negatives if continues to [**Doctor Last Name 1694**] based on respiratory culture
   -          Cont antibiotics as noted above, will stop flagyl if c.
   difficile toxin negative.
   -          Hold on repeat imaging of abd (would need contrast to fully
   evaluate), but if status dramatically worsens, would consider CT guided
   biopsy of pancreatis
   -          Appreciate surgical assistance.
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Suspect secondary to insensible fluid losses,
   significant diuresis.
           - D5W at 100cc/hr, follow up PM sodium
